document.docAuthor: Cruz Da Silva, Estevam L. & Carico, James E.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Thaumasia velox Simon, 1898b: 18
, male holotype from Rio Tocantins , São Paulo de Olivença, Amazonas, Brazil [ 03°23’S , 68°52’W ], de Mathan leg . (MNHN) (examined). F.O.
Pickard-Cambridge, 1901: 309
, pl. 30, fig. 5. F.O. Pickard- Cambridge, 1903: 154, pl. 14, fig. 1, female from Santarém, Pará, Brazil (MNHN).
Sierwald, 1989: 8
, figs. 13–16, 59–60.
Sierwald, 1990: 25
, figs. 16, 21.

Thaumasia annecta
Bryant, 1948: 349
, pl. 2, fig. 18, female from Ennery , Haiti ,
10.IX.1934
, P. J. Darlington (MCZ) (examined). New synonymy.

Thaumasia decemguttata
Mello-Leitão, 1945: 245
, fig. 28, two juveniles from Curuzú , Cuatiá , Corrientes , Argentina [ 29°47’S , 58°03’W ], M. Birabén ( MLP 16440 ) (examined).
New synonymy.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Newly established junior synonyms of
Thaumasia velox
.
The epigynum of the female type specimen of
T. annecta
is identical to
T. velox
. The juvenile types of
T. decemguttata
present a wide lateral band formed by short white bristles on the lateral area of carapace and abdomen, as the specimens of
T. velox
( Fig. 6 ).

Diagnosis. The males of
T. velox
resemble those of
T. scoparia
in the shape of the median apophysis ( Figs 144, 145 ), but can be distinguished by the short and ventrally curved tip of the ental branch of RTA ( Figs 58, 59 ) and also by the lamellar base of EnB ( Fig. 59 ). The females of
T. velox
resemble those of
T. caxiuana
sp. nov.
( Fig. 92 ),
T. senilis
( Fig. 26 ),
T. caracarai
sp. nov.
( Fig. 119 ) by the general shape of middle field of epigynum ( Fig. 60 ), but can be distinguished by the slightly excavated lateral portion of the middle field ( Fig. 60 ) and by the rounded and thickned border of the copulatory duct 2 ( Fig. 61 ) and by the short and rounded head of spermathecae ( Fig. 62 ).

Other material examined.

Distribution. Dominica , Panama , Ecuador , Colombia , Venezuela , Suriname , Trinidad-Tobago, Peru , Paraguay , Argentina , Brazil , Uruguay ( Fig. 3 ).
Natural history. Juveniles can be observed in web retreats built on leaves, on the vegetation near streams and lakes ( Fig. 5 ) (Silva field observations).
